instruction: What does Daniel Immerwahr mean by the 'logo map' and how has it hidden US empire?
response: Immerwahr argues that Americans carry a 'logo map' in their heads showing the United States as a contiguous landmass of states - the familiar shape used on logos from NBC to Major League Baseball. This map 'excludes all that was imperial' - the territories, colonies, and overseas possessions that have been part of the United States since 1898. When Roosevelt delivered his 'Day of Infamy' speech, he demoted the Philippines from the original draft, which described 'bombing in Hawaii and the Philippines,' to a single item in a terse list mixing US and British territories. The sixth-largest US city at the time (Manila) and sixteen million US nationals were rendered nearly invisible. A class of Michigan seventh-graders wrote to Rand McNally protesting that their atlas listed Hawaii as 'foreign.' The publisher replied that though Hawaii 'belongs to the United States, it is not an integral part of this country.' The girls called this 'an alibi instead of an explanation.' The logo map allowed Americans to think of themselves as living in an 'anti-imperial' nation even while governing millions of colonial subjects.

instruction: How does Immerwahr analyze the destruction of Manila in 1945 and what it reveals about US empire?
response: Immerwahr documents how Manila's destruction revealed the differential value of lives within the US empire. When Japanese Admiral Iwabuchi fortified the city for a final stand, US forces faced a choice. General Beightler's 37th Division believed in 'heavy firepower to the maximum' and reverted to its standard tactic: 'Rather than engage Iwabuchi's men in direct combat, it would simply destroy any buildings in which they might be hiding.' Beightler's logic was explicit: 'To me, the loss of a single American life to save a building was unthinkable.' But those buildings were inhabited by civilians who were also technically 'Americans' - US nationals. The result: for every mainland soldier killed, 100 Manilans died. The official toll: 1,010 US troops, 16,665 Japanese, and an estimated 100,000 Filipino civilians. Senator Tydings surveyed the aftermath: 'Destruction was so great that Manila had become, next to Warsaw, the most devastated city of World War II.' As usual, mainland lives were counted 'with to-the-last-digit precision, while Filipino fatality numbers were at best informed guesses.'

instruction: What was the Philippine-American War and how was Emilio Aguinaldo betrayed?
response: Immerwahr shows how the Philippine-American War began with betrayal. Aguinaldo had allied with the US against Spain, receiving assurances from Commodore Dewey and other officials that 'once the war was over, Filipinos would have their independence.' Dewey cabled 'TELL AGUINALDO COME SOON AS POSSIBLE' and Aguinaldo's forces 'took city after city' while the US Navy blockaded Manila Bay. But those promises 'never appeared in writing.' After McKinley decided to annex the Philippines ('educate the Filipinos, and uplift and civilize and Christianize them'), fighting broke out in February 1899. The war that followed 'made the war with Spain look like nothing' - 4,200 US soldiers died, more than ten times the Spanish-American War deaths, plus an estimated 775,000 Filipinos. McKinley's successor Roosevelt officially ended the war in 1902, but 'it would have been news to many in the Philippines that it was over.' Aguinaldo survived - 'he died in 1964 still unable to speak English.' His faith that Americans had come 'not from mercenary motives, but for the sake of humanity' had been brutally betrayed.

instruction: What were the Insular Cases and how did they create a two-tier constitutional system?
response: Immerwahr explains how the 1901 Insular Cases established that the Constitution didn't fully apply to US territories. The government argued that 'the United States' could mean either all territory under US jurisdiction or, narrowly, only the union of states. The Constitution's protections, the argument went, referred only to states, so 'territories thus had no right to constitutional protections, for the simple reason that the Constitution didn't apply to them.' The attorney general reminded justices that Congress could impose laws on territories 'without asking the consent of the inhabitants, even against their consent and against their protest.' The majority opinion warned about including 'savages' and 'alien races' within the constitutional fold. Unlike Plessy v. Ferguson (1896), which was overturned in Brown v. Board of Education, the Insular Cases 'are nevertheless still on the books, and they are still cited as good law.' Today, 'a citizen on the mainland has a constitutional right to trial by jury, but when that citizen travels to Puerto Rico, the right vanishes.' The court created 'practically two national governments, one bound by the Bill of Rights, the other not.'

instruction: How did standardization become a form of US imperial power according to Immerwahr?
response: Immerwahr reveals how the US achieved 'domination without annexation' through standards. Herbert Hoover as Commerce Secretary personally supervised the Bureau of Standards, convening industry conferences that standardized everything from bricks (66 varieties reduced to 11) to screw threads. The crucial battle was over screw thread angles: the US used 60 degrees, Britain 55 degrees. During WWII, 'we can't borrow parts from the British,' one mechanic complained. 'We can't even steal them. They don't fit.' The US spent $600 million compensating for incompatible screws. After the war, Britain 'simply surrendered' - adopting the 60-degree standard while 'U.S. manufacturers would barely notice the shift.' When the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) voted, other powers 'grumbled that the United States and Britain had beaten the gun' but had no choice. The US extended this to concert pitch (A440 hertz became global standard despite Austrian protests), aviation protocols, stop signs, and English itself. The privilege of global standardization: 'The United States has had the luxury of sticking to its ways while forcing other countries to retool their factories and retune their instruments.'

instruction: What does Immerwahr mean by the 'pointillist empire' and how did it replace territorial colonialism?
response: Immerwahr describes the US shift from territorial empire to a 'pointillist empire' of bases. During WWII, the US possessed 'an astonishing thirty thousand installations on two thousand overseas base sites.' New technologies - DDT, synthetic materials, aviation, radio - meant the US could project power without annexing territory. The Panama Canal Zone illustrates this: the US established 134 bases in Panama during WWII but then relinquished them all, eventually ceding the Canal Zone itself. 'It wasn't the canal that was obsolete - traffic through it continued to grow. It was the Canal Zone, which guaranteed access to the canal and granted control over it. That was the part that no longer seemed essential.' The Cold War was fought largely through bases and radio broadcasts rather than annexations. Soviet theorist Vladimir Slipchenko observed that 'area-based military concepts such as front, rear, and flank would be irrelevant. There would be only targets and non-targets.' The revolution in military affairs meant 'there will be no need to occupy enemy territory. Controlling territory wouldn't matter, because war was no longer about area. It was about points.'

instruction: How does Immerwahr connect Japan's postwar 'economic miracle' to the US base system?
response: Immerwahr shows Japan as the prime beneficiary of 'Baselandia' - territories hosting US military installations. The occupation initially devastated Japan, but the Korean War 'was a godsend.' Japanese firms supplied the men who fought: 'they drank Kirin beer, carried Nikon cameras, rode Honda motorbikes, and dropped bombs with Sony parts. The polyethylene body bags they came home in? Made in Japan.' Sony exemplified the pattern. Masaru Ibuka first saw a tape recorder when delivering equipment to occupation authorities. Engineers copied technical journals from a US-stocked library, then improvised with local materials - 'using the soft bristles from a raccoon's belly' to paint ferric oxide onto paper tape. Sony's transistor radios beat US competitors to market and 'effected a momentous shift in consumer culture' toward personal devices. By 1965 the trade balance flipped. California's governor described this as a 'colonial' relationship: 'We ship her raw materials, she ships us finished goods.' But success came at a cost: Japan 'surrendered a great deal of autonomy' and had to 'stand aside as the United States used Japanese land to launch Asian wars, spy on the Soviet Union, and store nuclear weapons.'

instruction: How does Immerwahr explain Osama bin Laden's attacks as a response to US empire?
response: Immerwahr traces bin Laden's trajectory through the base system. The bin Laden family construction firm built US military installations around Saudi Arabia. Osama's brothers studied engineering in the US; the firm retained a New York agent. When Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, bin Laden volunteered to fight but was rejected. Instead, King Fahd reopened Dhahran to US forces. This was the grievance bin Laden voiced 'consistently throughout his career': the stationing of troops in Saudi Arabia, which he called 'the American Crusader forces.' After the 1996 Dhahran bombing killed 19 US Air Force personnel, the military contracted for a $150 million remote compound. The builder hired by the Saudi government? The bin Laden firm. 'If there is one episode that perfectly captures the dual nature of the U.S. basing empire, it's this one. The Bin Ladens built the bases. A Bin Laden would seek to destroy them.' Bin Laden's chief objection was explicit: 'Your forces occupy our countries. You spread your military bases throughout them.' Immerwahr concludes: 'September 11 was, in large part, retaliation against the United States for its empire of bases.'

instruction: What does Immerwahr reveal about Guam's ongoing colonial status in the US empire?
response: Immerwahr shows Guam as the empire's 'useful' possession - valuable precisely because it remains a territory without full rights. When the military planned to relocate forces from Okinawa, Guam was the destination. A graduate student who interviewed an Air Force analyst heard the colonial logic stated bluntly: 'People on Guam were forgetting that they are a possession, and not an equal partner. If California says they want to do this or that, it is like my wife saying that she wants to move here or there: I'll have to respect her wish and at least discuss it with her. If Guam says they want to do this or that, it is as if this cup here,' the analyst said, pointing to his coffee mug, 'expresses a wish: the answer will be, you belong to me and I can do with you as best I please.' Professor LisaLinda Natividad protested: 'This is old-school colonialism all over again. It boils down to our political status - we are occupied territory.' Guam also proved useful for the 'dark side' Dick Cheney announced after 9/11 - the territory's lack of full constitutional protections made it suitable for detention and interrogation operations that would be illegal on the mainland.

instruction: How did English become a tool of US imperial control according to Immerwahr?
response: Immerwahr analyzes English as 'a standard, just like stop signs and screw threads, but running much deeper.' In the colonies, the government made English 'the cardinal point of the whole Philippine school system.' Students were expected to work in English; civil servants had to use it; in the Virgin Islands, English proficiency was required for voting. Nursing students were 'hived off from the general population' and drilled in English, mainland food, and mainland etiquette - 'sandals were replaced by shoes, long dresses by crisp gingham worn over stockings.' The effect persisted after independence: 'the Philippines has remained, even after independence, extraordinarily U.S.-centric in its nursing practices.' Churchill recognized language as key to 'empires of the mind' and promoted Basic English - 850 words, 18 verbs - as 'English for foreigners.' After WWII, with the US dominating global communications and the military broadcasting A440 concert pitch worldwide, English spread globally. The result: US inhabitants 'can travel to nearly any spot on the map, confident that someone within hailing distance will speak their language.' A world, Immerwahr writes, 'almost designed for the convenience of the United States. A world of Squantos.'

instruction: What does Immerwahr's analysis reveal about the relationship between anti-imperialism and US empire?
response: Immerwahr exposes the contradiction at the heart of US self-understanding. Americans consistently imagine themselves as 'anti-imperial' while governing an empire. After 1898, even as the US annexed the Philippines, Puerto Rico, Guam, Hawaii, and Samoa, 'the c-word became taboo.' An official admonished in 1914: 'The word colony must not be used to express the relationship which exists between our government and its dependent peoples.' The euphemism 'territories' obscured the difference between frontier territories destined for statehood and permanent colonies 'not obviously slated for statehood.' The logo map reinforced this blindness - most mainlanders 'had never even seen a Filipino, a Puerto Rican, or a Hawaiian.' After WWII, the US developed new forms of control: standardization, bases, linguistic hegemony. 'We covet no one's land,' Rumsfeld repeated. Yet as Immerwahr shows, 'if the Bush administration had no evident lust for sheer acreage, there were certain small spots that it cared about very much.' The pointillist empire replaced the territorial empire, but empire continued. The self-image of anti-imperialism became itself an imperial tool - hiding the empire in plain sight.

instruction: How does Immerwahr analyze the racial logic connecting the Insular Cases to Jim Crow segregation?
response: Immerwahr connects the Insular Cases directly to Plessy v. Ferguson. 'Eight of the nine justices who decided the 1901 Insular Cases also decided Plessy v. Ferguson (1896), the notorious case that upheld the constitutionality of separate but equal Jim Crow institutions.' Both rulings divided the country into separate spaces with different rights. 'Plessy permitted segregation, the division of the country into separate spaces, some reserved for whites, others for nonwhites. The Insular Cases split the country into what one justice called practically two national governments, one bound by the Bill of Rights, the other not.' The racial logic was explicit: the majority opinion 'contained warnings about including savages and alien races within the constitutional fold. Doing so, one of the justices concurred, would wreck our institutions, perhaps leading the whole structure of the government to be overthrown.' But there is a critical difference: 'In 1954, in Brown v. Board of Education, the Supreme Court overturned Plessy.' The Insular Cases, far less known, 'are nevertheless still on the books, and they are still cited as good law.' The racial partition of 1901 remains constitutional doctrine.
